Posts.Content: I went in for an MRI this month after being initially diagnosed in July. My docs recommendation is to continue on AS with a PSA every 4 months and another biopsy next summer. I dont have much on an idea on what any of this says (see results below) but wouldn't mind thoughts or opinions from those of you who have been dealing with this type of thing for a while. You guys have always been helpful, thanks in advance. INDICATION: MALIGNANT NEOPLASM OF PROSTATE. Patient reports a 5 month history of prostate cancer, 3+3 = 6, PSA 3.5. TECHNIQUE: 1. T1 and T2-weighted MRI pelvis without and with gadolinium utilizing phased array body coil. 2. Multiphasic dynamic enhancement of the prostate. 3. Diffusion-weighted imaging of the pelvis and prostate. 4. Study was processed using DynaCad multiparametric computer-aided detection system to optimize radiologist interpretation by generating multiplanar and 3D reconstructions and creating subtraction images from the dynamic contrast data. CONTRAST: 17 ml Dotarem. MEDICATIONS: Glucagon 1 mL IV. COMPARISON: None. FINDINGS: BONES: Negative. SEMINAL VESICLES: Negative. PELVIC LYMPH NODES: Negative. PROSTATE GLAND VOLUME: 5.2 x 4.5 x 4.4 cm, 50.7 mL. PERIPHERAL ZONE: In the right posterolateral peripheral zone in the base, there is a focal T2 hypointense nodule on image 19 measuring 0.8 x 0.6 x 1.1 cm, with associated restricted diffusion in the range of 800-900 x 10 -6mm 2/s. No associated extracapsular extension. This is a Pl-RADS 4 finding. TRANSITIONAL ZONE: No focal abnormalities. Mild prominence of the transitional zone with probable benign prostatic hyperplasia changes. This study was seen in consultation with Dr. Peter Wold, who concurred with this interpretation.
Posts.Signature: DOB 4/11/1969 psa: 5/12: 3.46, 3/13: 2.38, 3/14: 3.49 6/15: 3.10 7/16: 3.19 12/1: 3.5 Nodule found during DPE 7/2016 Biopsy 7/22/2016 RMB: adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 Total surface area 5% involved perineural invasion present
Posts.Title: MRI results Any thoughts?

Posts.Content: Thanks for the replies, I appreciate it! ASAdvocate...What is a PHI vs a PSA? Ill have to ask my urologist about it when I go in for my next PSA. I didnt get any genetic testing done after my biopsy because the amount of cancerous tissue that they extracted wasnt big enough to to any tests on. Hopefully next summer when I have another biopsy they will be able to target the tumor better with the MRI results and get a bigger sample to do some genetics testing on

Posts.Content: I was just reading on another thread about physical and sexual activity affecting PSA levels. I didn't want to hijack his thread so I thought I would start a new one. Im going in for my first PSA and MRI this month after my biopsy and diagnosis last July. Im am currently doing the AS route and would like to make sure my PSA numbers are accurate. What are activities that can raise PSA readings that I should avoid? I am a pretty active person and run several times a week and am getting into riding my bike more often since I can do that on the trainer in the basement when the weather is crap outside. The pathetic part of my life as I get older is that I would be more OK with missing sexual activity for a couple days before a PSA test than I would be with missing a run day.
Posts.Signature: DOB 4/11/1969 psa: 5/12: 3.46, 3/13: 2.38, 3/14: 3.49 6/15: 3.10 7/16: 3.19 12/1: 3.5 Nodule found during DPE 7/2016 Biopsy 7/22/2016 RMB: adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 Total surface area 5% involved perineural invasion present
Posts.Title: PSA and physical activity

Posts.Content: ASAdvocate...Thanks for the encouraging words. Its nice to hear from somebody who is still healthy after being on AS for so long. With any luck I will be able to keep waiting until better treatment options become available or maybe even indefinitely.
Posts.Signature: DOB 4/11/1969 psa: 5/12: 3.46, 3/13: 2.38, 3/14: 3.49 6/15: 3.10 7/16: 3.19 12/1: 3.5 Nodule found during DPE 7/2016 Biopsy 7/22/2016 RMB: adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 Total surface area 5% involved perineural invasion present
Posts.Title: NEW -New England Journal of Medicine article... and associated NY Times article on it

Posts.Content: As someone who has recently joined the active surveillance club, I read all 3 articles and Im still not sure how I feel. While I think that its trying to convey that AS is a viable option for early cancer, I tend to pick out the negatives from the articles just as Michael has in the previous post. I think the hardest part is trying to be patient, which isn't one of my strong points. It doesn't help when you are telling people about your prostate cancer who aren't familiar with treatment options and you tell them that you are just going to keep and eye on things for a year or two and they look at you like your f-ing nuts.
Posts.Signature: DOB 4/11/1969 psa: 5/12: 3.46, 3/13: 2.38, 3/14: 3.49 6/15: 3.10 7/16: 3.19 12/1: 3.5 Nodule found during DPE 7/2016 Biopsy 7/22/2016 RMB: adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 Total surface area 5% involved perineural invasion present
Posts.Title: NEW -New England Journal of Medicine article... and associated NY Times article on it

Posts.Content: So, first post here and I'm more than a little overwhelmed. I'm 47 and was just diagnosed with PC yesterday. My PSA's have been relatively low, my last one a few weeks ago was 3.1 which is actually lower than the 3.4 I had 2 years ago. My Dr discovered a nodule during a DPE and referred me to a urologist who did a biopsy last week. I didnt do enough research ahead of time so I don't know and diddn't know to ask the gleason score numbers or any of that. He basically said that everything was contained in the prostate and that if I was in my 70's he probably wouldn't do anything, but since Im in my 40's we need to figure out a plan. I go back and see him to discuss things on August 12. My father and 2 uncles all had PC and were treated with surgery and all have survived. I guess Im not sure why I posted just yet other than to jump in and join the goup. I'm sure I'm going to have many questions in the coming weeks and months. None of the treatment plans sound particularly pleasant so some experienced advice will be very helpful. Thanks for listening
Posts.Title: Might as well jump right in

Posts.Content: I got my pathology report today: E) PROSTATE, RIGHT MEDIAL BASE, NEEDLE BIOPSY 1. Adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 6 (3+3); see note 2. Total surface area involved: 5% 3. Number of needle biopsy cores involved 2 of 2 4. Perineural invasion: present 5. High grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia All of the 11 other sections came up as benign. From what I can tell, it doesnt look too bad as far as prostate cancer goes, but I would rather have no cancer as Im sure the rest of you would also. I dont go in for my consult until the 12th and Im having a hard time being patient. I'm planning on a second opinion but I'm not sure if I should make the appt now or wait until after my first opinion. What is usually required for the second? Do they just need to pathology report from the biopsy? If Im feeling motivated today I might try to update my signature
Posts.Title: Might as well jump right in

Posts.Content: Thank you everybody for your kind words and well wishes...makes me wonder what people did for support before the internet. I have emailed my doctor for more info my biopsy and will post it as soon as I know. I have also ordered Walsh's book and started to do my research. There is a lot of info to digest...is there a thread on here that addresses all the different acronyms and terms? After getting through the initial shock and letting all of the important people in my life know what's going on,Im ready to adjust my attitude and dig in. I just ran my first marathon in june and Im training for another which I hope wont get derailed, Im in the best shape of my life, Im at my fighting weight and Im ready to go!! Thanks again for the support. Oh and lastly, Michael F asked if I was planning on more children....no way, I have 4 boys already so if anybody wants one, I have extra

Posts.Content: When I was talking to my urologist about surgery options he noticed from my record that I have had previous hernia surgery and kindof grimaced and asked if there was a bunch of mesh in there. I asked if that would be a problem and he bushed if off and said that it can just be a bit more tricky. Has anybody else heard this or had any experience with it? Its been something that been stuck in my head for the last couple of days.
Posts.Signature: DOB 4/11/1969 psa: 5/12: 3.46, 3/13: 2.38, 3/14: 3.49 6/15: 3.10 7/16: 3.19 12/1: 3.5 Nodule found during DPE 7/2016 Biopsy 7/22/2016 RMB: adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 Total surface area 5% involved perineural invasion present
Posts.Title: Da Vinci surgery and previous hernias

Posts.Content: Thank you everybody for the advice and good thoughts...its truly helpful. The other factor that I weighing in is my lifestyle. Im very active and love to run, cycle an golf weekly and have enjoyed being fit. I ran my first marathon in June and would love to be able to do another one. For any runners/athletes out there that have had surgery, how long did it take afterwards to get back in the groove of things and were you able to get back to where you were before surgery? Its a double edged sword knowing that I would be able to handle surgery well being in good shape, but knowing that if I do go in the surgery will set me back a long ways and I might never be the same in some aspects.

Posts.Title: Need to decide - what would you do and why did you choose it?

Posts.Content: Judging from all the experience and thoughtfulness of the members here, wondered if anyone would share their thoughts on the following: Background: (signature line) otherwise healthy 47 year old. PSA has been hovering in the 3's for 3 years and doctor identified a nodule during DRE. Biospy returned Gleason 3+3 in one core with 5% surface area. Option 1: Active surveillance for next year - MRI in fall with additional PSA tests and biopsy next July. Option 2: Robotic prostate removal. We will be visiting another doctor on Monday for 2nd opinion, so that will help to make the final determination. Thanks in advance for weighing in.
Posts.Signature: DOB 4/11/1969 psa: 5/12: 3.46, 3/13: 2.38, 3/14: 3.49 6/15: 3.10 7/16: 3.19 12/1: 3.5 Nodule found during DPE 7/2016 Biopsy 7/22/2016 RMB: adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6 Total surface area 5% involved perineural invasion present
Posts.Title: Need to decide - what would you do and why did you choose it?

Posts.Content: I do have a family history which weighs heavily on my decision. My father was treated for PC at 54, he also has 2 brothers that have been treated for prostate cancer, a sister who died of breast cancer and my Grandma died with breast cancer. Not really a great family history. The thing that I am hesitant about is doing active surveillance fora year or two, but I will still be in the same boat that I am today and still have to make the same decision again.

Posts.Title: Need to decide - what would you do and why did you choose it?

Posts.Content: I have been lurking on here for a while now, but haven't posted in a long time. I have been on active surveillance for almost 3 years (June of 16 I was diagnosed). My PSA has been slowly rising, in December it was 4.1 and at the end of March it was up to 4.5. My urologist wants to check once more at the end of June and if its the same or up he wants to start treatment. I haven't discussed treatment options with him since I was first diagnosed, but I'm assuming that its going to be RALP. In a way I'm almost relieved to be doing something because its felt like I have been walking around with a live grenade inside of me but on the other hand I'm obviously worried about the surgery and after effects. I'm sure I will have plenty of questions moving forward but for now I just have a couple. How long should I plan on being out of work? I have a desk job and don't do anything too strenuous. How long does it usually take to be able to get back to regular exercise again? I was signed up to run a marathon this fall to celebrate turning 50 this year but I'm guessing that will need to be postponed.

Posts.Title: Nearing the end of active surveillance

Posts.Content: Thanks for the responses. I think one of the underlying reasons that my doc is looking at treatment sooner than later is my family history of prostate cancer. My dad and all three of his brothers have had their prostates removed along with his mom and sister having breast cancer. I believe I have a significant target on my back. IÂll have a more in depth conversation with my doc after my next psa. I have been trying to get ahead on the kegel exercises when I remember. I need to come up with something to remind me to do them at certain times of the day.
